page.shortlink: ux controls other controls button control advanced button styling
page.description: When they are initially added to a component most buttons are somewhat bland. Changing the text and images on a button control, however, is easy.

section.description: For an illustration of styling options follow the guide below or watch [this video].

step.description: In the UX Builder on the UX Controls page open the 'Other Controls' menu. Click on the [Button] option to add a button control to the component.

Highlight the button control in the controls tree. In the properties list, in the Button Properties section, set the 'Advanced button control type' property dropdown to 'Button', 'Hyperlink', or 'Image'.
step.note: Selecting Image here means that the button will only be the image. As such, the button will have no border around it.

step.description: View the 'Button Appearance' section of the properties list. The property settings in this section will change depending on the advanced button control type selected.

section.title: Specifying an Image
section.description: You can use system images, imported images, svg images, an external url, or css images on a button control.

step.description: Create an image to use for the button.

After creating a button control, go to the properties list and set the 'Advanced button control type' property to'Button'. Scroll down to the 'Button Appearance' section and click the [...] button next to the 'Image name' property.
In the Specify Image dialog use the radio buttons to select the type of image you want to use. In this case "Image in Web Project or Style".
Click the "Add Image to Project" button.
In the "Add Image to Project" dialog click the up arrow next to the 'Source filename' textbox.
Select the images file extension from the dropdown in the lower-right hand corner. Then select the image you want to use and click Open. Click OK and OK again.
Run the component in Live Preview.

section.title: Adding Different Images for Different Button States
section.description: A common design feature used with buttons in an application is to change a button's styling when the state of the button changes. For example, when the button is hovered over the color of the text or image on the button might change. Similar changes can also occur when the button is pressed or disabled.

section.title: Button Layout
section.description: If you select 'Button' from the 'Advanced button control type' property dropdown, then you can add both an image and text to the button. You can also add just an image or some text. The placement of the image and text on the button can be specified using the 'Button layout' property. Selecting the 'Image only' option here is different from selecting 'Image' in the 'Advanced button control type' property. The 'Image only' setting here will also only show an image, but this image will usually have an automatic border placed around it.
